question: Hey, O'Donnell, save some for the game.
answer: Just warming up, Coach.

question: First game of the season and the scouts are already lining up. You have half the season I know you're capable of, you can play anywhere you want, Mike.
answer: That's the plan coach.

question: Round up, Jock Straps! Picture time.
answer: Hold on. Ed's not here yet.

question: Scar! Wait.
answer: I'm not sure if its my Qi or internal bleeding.

question: What are you doing now?
answer: There he is. There's Mr. Sunshine. Fei Jing Acupuncture. It's all the rage. Makes you look five years younger. What's this brown stuff again? Delish! The girl has absolutely no clue what she's doing.

question: Then why are you letting her stick needles in you?
answer: Because she's hot. But today's not about me. It's about you becoming the new regional sales manager.

question: I better be. I've invested 18 years of my life in that miserable company.
answer: No negativity. Negativity's for the 800 pound fat lady who needs to be airlifted out of bed. You, Michael Shawn O'Donnell, are a winner.

question: A winner doesn't have to crash at his best friend's house because he was kicked out of his own house.
answer: Are you kidding?! It doesn't get any better than this! I gotta get back. My legs just went numb. Good luck today.

question: Thanks, Wendy. That like totally means so much to me.
answer: Good morning, peeps. As you all know, today I'll be naming the new regional sales manager. What's it take to be an RSM? Leadership skills, a comprehensive knowledge of today's prescription pharmaceuticals and most importantly a dedicated soldier. All being said, congratulations- Wendy. Now go out there and sell some drugs peeps!

question: How could you do this to me? I've been a salesman here 18 years. Wendy's only been here 2 months!?
answer: Look, your sales are admittedly better but she has the college degree. What can I do?

question: You can give me the promotion, Roger!
answer: Things have changed. I couldn't even hire you now with only a high school diploma. My hands are tied, bro-ski.

question: Alex? 3, 2, 1- The kid's still got it. Ooooh. That was stupid. I do. Me. I'm in the center there.
answer: Adolescence can be so cruel.

question: What are you talking about? (lost in the picture
answer: `For of all sad words of tongue and pen, the saddest are these

question: That'll be my epitaph.
answer: We all have regrets.

question: Why's it have to be that way?
answer: Maybe it does, maybe it doesn't. Can't hurt to ask. You never know who's listening, Michael.

question: How did you know...
answer: ...What are you doing, Dad?

question: Hey, Guys. I was just talking to- Never mind. Sorry I'm late. You ready to get some dinner then?
answer: Why are you limping?

question: Tweaked my back pumping iron. Really, really heavy iron. I bet your chompin' at the bit for hoop season to start.
answer: Yeah, me and the guys are running drills, scrimmaging, getting in shape.

question: That's my boy. Remember, it's not how big you are-
answer: -it's how big you play.

question: You did!? That's fantastic!
answer: It's no big deal.

question: It's a huge deal. That's a great university. I'm proud of you. Am I missing something here?
answer: You wouldn't understand.

question: Try me.
answer: I have a lot of emotional stress right now. My friends are all going to different schools, I'm not even sure...

question: That's not stress. Wait `til you get out into the real world, get a crappy job, have some smarmy twerp- boss calling you bro-ski...
answer: Did you get the promotion, Dad?

question: Still waiting to hear. Is your mom home?
answer: She's probably out back.

question: Bite me, Dom. A little late for a delivery isn't it?
answer: Dom was in the neighborhood. He offered to make a dump run for me.

question: Doesn't he live 30 miles from here?
answer: What's your point?

question: Come on. He's been after you since 10th grade and he's after you now.
answer: At least someone's after me.

question: `In touch with the ground, I'm on the hunt I'm after you.'
answer: Please, Mike. This isn't high school. That's not gonna work.

question: `Smell like I sound, I'm lost in a crowd, and I'm hungry like the wolf.'
answer: You can stop now. It's not working.

question: `Mouth is alive, with juices like wine, and I'm hungry like the wolf'
answer: You no longer have the right to invoke the "wolf."

question: Why are you destroying the yard?
answer: I'm gonna use it as a showpiece for clients. Thanks for asking.

question: Kind of a big undertaking isn't it?
answer: I am a landscape designer. Then again you barely took an interest in my work so I guess that's a fair question.

question: I didn't get it.
answer: I'm sorry. But maybe this is what you needed. Maybe it's time you looked for something else?

question: That's a great idea, Scar. Because there are so many options out there for a 36 year old with only a high school diploma.
answer: And it's all my fault, isn't it?

question: I didn't say that.
answer: No, but it's what you think, right? I never asked you to marry me.

question: But I did.
answer: I'm sorry you're not happy with the way your life turned out Mike, really, I am, but you're not the victim here.

question: Jesus! Hey!? Get away from there!? Oh no!! Hello!? What the- Damn it. Ed! Ed! I lost my key!
answer: Coming! I've been worried sick!

question: I've had a really rough night.
answer: AAAAAHHHHHHHHH!!!!! Don't come any closer! I'll use it!

question: What are you gonna do? Exfoliate me to death? You got into my samples case again, didn't you? What's your problem, it's only mud. AAAAAAAAHHHHHHH!!! AHHHHHHHHHHHH!!! I'm dreaming right? Is this some kind of hallucination? Do something! Anything! Pinch me! I said pinch! Calm down! We need to talk! We can work this out!
answer: Maria, we're just friends. Really. My theory is that you were transformed by a freak congruence of some of the planets most volatile elements. I've recreated the exact contents of the LA River. The toxic pollutants, the contaminants.

question: Well, it obviously isn't working.
answer: That's because the cocktail's not complete. Last night we had the worst electrical storm of the last hundred years.

question: Is that true?
answer: It was pretty bad.

question: Wait!! Wait!! Wait!! Do you really think this'll work?
answer: It could. Oops. Came unplugged. Won't be a moment. What were you doing by the river anyway?

question: The janitor! Has anyone seen the janitor? Is the janitor here? Where's the janitor? Excuse me! Excuse me!? Can you tell me where I can find the night janitor?
answer: I'm the only custodial engineer currently employed here.

question: There was an old guy, white hair. I showed him this picture of me-
answer: -Of you? That picture's from 1989.

question: Right. Forget it. Alex? What are you doing up there?
answer: I wanted to see if I could get my nuts into my esophagus. What do you think I'm doing!? Get me down!

question: Okay. Okay. I'll get you down.
answer: How do you know my name?

question: I'm...Mark...Freedman. Your Uncle Ed's son. He told me to look out for you.
answer: Uncle Ed has a son?

question: Believe me, it's gonna be a surprise to him too. Did those guys do this to you?
answer: Goons from the basketball team.

question: But why?
answer: Because they can and so they do on a daily basis. No, I'm not. Nice robe, guy. Gotta go.

question: Did you find the janitor?
answer: He doesn't exist. Nothing makes sense.

question: Did he ask you for your soul?
answer: No?

question: That's a good sign. We can eliminate Satan. I think what we're dealing with here is a spell of enlightenment. "Spell affect"..."casting procedure"...yada, yada, yada. Basically it's a learning spell. There's something you need to figure out and until you do you'll stay a kid. My guess is that janitor was probably a war...
answer: ...I'm going back to high school.

question: ...lock. I'm sorry. Could you repeat that? Because I thought you just said you were-
answer: Going back to high school.

question: Are you out of your freaking mind!?
answer: My son was hanging by his underwear from a bathroom stall door and my daughter was being mauled by a smarmy gorilla. They need me.

question: What about your job?
answer: Email and telephone. I got it covered.

question: Well, Scarlet, then. What are you gonna tell her?
answer: Nothing.

question: You're just gonna disappear?
answer: To be honest, I think she'd rather have it that way. What's with the attitude?

question: Because I know you're going to suck me into this and I'm not going back there, Mike. You'll never get me to go back to Fitch. Never! I hate you.
answer: Take a deep breath. All you have to do is enroll me and say as little as possible. Are you sure these look legit?

question: Please. I created software used to launch the space shuttle. I think I'm capable of forging some report cards. What's up with the gear?
answer: This is hip teenage apparel. I got it right off the mannequin at Ed Hardy.

question: I think it's time we got Mark to class. Lisa! Lisa! Lisa, will you print out a schedule for Mark and show him to class?
answer: Be a good boy now. And sit up straight. They grow up so fast. Mojito?

question: I beg your pardon.
answer: You strike me as a Mojito gal. I know this little Cuban place, great

question: -Yeah, no. I don't date my students' parents. It's a rule of mine.
answer: I'll enroll him somewhere else.

question: I really need to get back to work.
answer: See you at the next bake sale then?

question: If you flunk senior calculus you'll be lucky to get into beauty school, missy. So, if you plan on slacking your way through my class, don't. Save your parents tuition money and pick up a blow dryer...
answer: Enough!

question: Excuse me?
answer: Do you think humiliating a 17 year- old in front of her peers is helpful or do you just get off on it?

question: And you are?
answer: Mark Freedman. It's my first day.

question: Well, Mr. Freedman- -you've earned yourself a trip to the principal's office. Welcome to Fitch.
answer: Is someone barbecuing?

question: It was terrible. The place is evil, Ed. That building needs to be exorcised.
answer: Come on. It couldn't have been that bad.

question: My beanbag was lit on fire, videoed and sent to every member of student body.
answer: Yeah, I caught it on youtube. Funny stuff.

question: They mocked my clothes and phone. My daughter got a tongue bath in front of me and I have mint chip in my ears.
answer: High school's great, isn't it?

question: Double scotch neat.
answer: Get the boy a Shirley Temple. Extra cherries.

question: I'm not going back there.
answer: Mike, you're an adult sitting on 36 years of experience. You should be dominating these kids, ripping their hearts out.

question: I know why you're encouraging me all of a sudden.
answer: Because I'm a supportive dad.

question: Because you want to nail my principal.
answer: Did she ask about me?

question: She's not your type. She's smart.
answer: As far as I can tell that's her only flaw. I need a reason to see her again. You could flunk your classes, start a fight, vandalise the place. You'll figure it out. Then I can rush in, a teary eyed, helpless, single dad who can't handle his angry, kitten killing son. What do you think? Mind your business, Lady. This is a family matter.

question: I can't do it. I don't have it in me.
answer: Hey, no sweat off my sack. Tell Alex to stop wearing underwear all together. He'll be fine. That's what I did.

question: You're right! My kids need me.
answer: At'a boy. Now what you need is a crash course on being a teen in Before you ask, it's a seaweed wrap. I'm detoxifying as well as losing an inch or 2 from my problem areas.

question: There must be a very hot girl downstairs.
answer: There is. What are you doing?

question: I forwarded my calls to my new phone, sent some work emails and just lobbed one to Scarlet, told her I was in Peru finding myself. Think she'll buy it?
answer: Probably not because when she called earlier I told her you were being detained at Guantanamo. Ready for tomorrow?

question: I am so ready.
answer: That ought'a put you over the top. And don't forget to hook me up son.

question: So I've been here a couple days now and I think I got it figured out. You girls are lesbians, right? Mind if I sit here?
answer: Mark? You look totally different.

question: I got rid of the bull's eye on my forehead.
answer: Could you move to the left a little?

question: Who's she?
answer: Nicole Lopez. She's in my Spanish class.

question: Have you spoken to her?
answer: No. I get all stupid so I just stare.

question: I'll tell you a funny story. The first time I met your mother I was so nervous-
answer: My mother?

question: What?
answer: You said, `the first time I met your mother I was so nervous...'

question: I did? That's weird. Is your mom hot?
answer: Dude.

question: What's going on tonight? You wanna hang out? Do something?
answer: Really?

question: Yeah you could show me around.
answer: Cool.

question: I'll swing by your house around 7.
answer: I wouldn't go over there. Stan and his Baboons have lunch this period.

question: Man, I feel great! I even shot some hoops after school. No aches. No pains. Gotta run, Buddy.
answer: I've been dying to meet you. I've known your father since...

question: Is something wrong?
answer: And you say Ed Freedman is your father?

question: That's my dad. All 68 inches of him.
answer: You don't look anything like him. If you don't mind me asking, who's your mother?

question: My mother...she...she was...a... -a convict. In New Jersey. They met while dad was at Princeton. She was on parole. B&E, fist fighting, shanking. Nothing major. But she's dead now.
answer: Oh? I'm sorry.

question: I warned her about kite surfing during hurricane season. So how are things with you? Doing anything exciting? Dating? Flirting with Dom Johnson maybe?
answer: Why would you ask about Dom? Did Ed tell you to say that?

question: I mean do what you want. You're a grown woman but, word on the street is Dom's been spreading gingivitis all over town.
answer: I'll keep that in mind, Mark. It's crazy how much you like my husband when he was a teenager.

question: You doing some gardening?
answer: I am. I'm a landscape designer. I'm actually redoing the backyard. I'll show you. It's a work in progress so you'll have to use your imagination some.

question: I almost don't even recognize it...er...if I had seen it before I probably wouldn't recognize it.
answer: You wouldn't have. It was a disaster back here a few days ago. Obviously I have a lot to do still. I'm laying the sod next and the limestone pathway will go here. Then I'll plant all those, over a hundred different types of flowers and plants. I have an amazing fountain being delivered that'll go here and a bench over there. And I'll string rows of tiny, white lights above it all so every night will be a starry one. It'll be a real sanctuary back here.

question: It seems like a lot'a work for one person, Scar.
answer: My husband's the only one that ever calls me that.

question: How's your mom doing? You know, with your dad not being around and all.
answer: She doesn't like to show it but I know she's bummed. I think it bothers her more that he hasn't called me or Maggie in a while. Whatever.

question: I have no idea what this says?
answer: It says `What up? Mobbing it to Zuma. So over it but whatever. Be right back. Back. Got to go. Talk to you later. kiss, hug. Sam.

question: This looks boring. Let's go back to my house and play video games.
answer: What are you so nervous about?

question: The beach is for the older, cool kids. I don't belong here.
answer: What are you talking about? You're a basketball player. You're cool.

question: I don't play basketball. I mean, I can play, I just don't play on the team.
answer: But I thought you were getting ready for the season?

question: Oh, man. It's her. She's here.
answer: Who?

question: She's so pretty it makes me gassy.
answer: Calm down. Here's what you're gonna do. You're gonna go over there and introduce yourself-

question: She won't like me, Mark. I'm a loser.
answer: Why? Because Stan says so? You think Stan's a winner? He's going nowhere. You're a great kid. Any girl would be lucky to get your attention.

question: Really?
answer: Really. And right now, there's a girl over there who's dying to meet you.

question: Okay. What do I say?
answer: Just introduce yourself. Then compliment her on something she never gets complimented on. Like if she has big, meaty, man hands tell her she should be a hand model. And don't burp on her.

question: Hi.
answer: Hi, Alex. I'm Nicole.

question: You don't look like a Nicole.
answer: You have big, meaty man hands. You should be a hand model.

question: Oh my God! Seriously!?
answer: Wait. I'm sorry. I'm just real nervous and I've wanted to talk to you for so long. And Mark told me to compliment you on something you never get complimented on but I couldn't find anything because everything's so...perfect.

question: What do you want?
answer: Stan. Why are you dating him?

question: Get to the point why don't you?
answer: I'm serious. He's not a nice guy. Matter of fact he's a jackass.

question: Don't talk about him like that. You don't even know him.
answer: I know he bullies your brother.

question: Stan barely knows Alex exists. We're moving in together after graduation.
answer: Whoa. Whoa. Whoa. I thought you were going to Georgetown?

question: I'm going to Westwood Community College. Stan and I both are.
answer: The hell you are, Young Lady! If you think I'm gonna let you throw your life away on some Sleestack you're crazy! I forbid you to see him anymore and that's final!

question: Who do you think you are!? My father?!
answer: Don't you walk away from me, Margaret Sarah O'Donnell!

question: What was that all about?
answer: That envelope contains divorce papers. But what do you care? You're going to college, right? Life's one big panty raid for you.

question: I don't know what you're talking about?
answer: I saw the applications in your room.

question: You went through my room!?
answer: If you'd cleaned like I asked I wouldn't have had to. You can't be serious about this can you?

question: I have to face the possibility that I might never turn back and if that's the case, I'm going to do it right this time around.
answer: Karmically speaking, in the next life you're coming back as a hemorrhoid. I'm not paying for college!

question: You like her, don't you?
answer: Who?

question: My girlfriend. She told me you were trashing me at the beach.
answer: Leave her alone, Stan. She's a good kid.

question: I don't know how good she is yet but after I find out, she's all yours.
answer: Settle, people. This was your homework. Who can come up here and solve this for me? Anyone? Not one person. Fine. Miss O'Donnell. Come up here and dazzle us with your brilliance.

question: Stuck!!! I'm stuck! My fingers!
answer: Sit down, Stan! Sit down!

question: I got your text. What's so important?
answer: This year you're making the team. We practice everyday `til try outs. That gives us a week and a half.

question: Forget it.
answer: Yeah, you're right. You probably don't have any skills anyway.

question: Hey! I got skills.
answer: So what's your problem? Is it Stan and his friends?

question: Just leave it alone.
answer: You don't need to be afraid of them, Alex.

question: I'm too small anyway.
answer: That's why we focus on your speed, dribbling and outside shot. Remember, it's not how big you are-

question: -it's how big you play.
answer: Alright. You got a little game.

question: Alright. You got a little game.
answer: What are you 2 queers doing in my gym?

question: Let's go, Alex.
answer: I don't think so. You girls wanna play with the boys then let's play. 2 on 2.

question: We'll save you the embarrassment for try-outs.
answer: Come on, Ally. Embarrass me.

question: Alex, I'll meet you at the car. I need to talk to Uncle Ed for a second. Did you give him the divorce papers?
answer: I sent them to him.

question: Is it another woman? I can handle it. Tell me the truth.
answer: I haven't heard from him, really.

question: Okay. If you do, please have him call home. For the kids...I'm running out of excuses-
answer: I'll tell him. I promise.

question: I'll tell him. I promise.
answer: Ed, come on in.

question: I'll take it from here. I'm heartbroken. The boy's incorrigible.
answer: Look, if it was only one isolated fight it wouldn't distress me all that much. Boys will be boys. But, it's also been brought to my attention that Mark may have Krazy glued a boy to his chair.

question: See? The boy's out of control. He's acting up at home. He won't eat his vegetables-
answer: Enough! Mark, I know it's hard to be the new kid but if I have anymore trouble from you, you'll be facing detentions or worse. You can go now.

question: He's crying out for help and I don't know what to do. It hurts so bad. Maybe we could discuss this over margaritas?
answer: Let's give him time to figure it out on his own. If the situation gets worse then we'll take the next step.

question: Gloves are for sissies.
answer: Yeah, but I just had a manicure. Are you kidding? I love landscaping! It's right up there with watching "Sex and the City" and snuggling.

question: Mark, I'm 36 years old-
answer: I'm just doing this to make a few bucks so I can buy Laker tickets. Wow. 10 whole dollars. At that rate I should be able to buy tickets in...2011.

question: Fine. 20. Grab a roll.
answer: What are the benefits like here?

question: I'll throw in a baloney sandwich.
answer: Deal. Maggie?

question: Deal. Maggie?
answer: What do you want? To rub it in my face? Say I told you so?

question: You lost me?
answer: Stan dumped me.

question: What happened? What did he do? You didn't...
answer: My mom was working last night. Stan came over with a box of-

question: Your next word better be `cookies' or you're in big, big trouble!
answer: What am I going to do? I can't live without him.

question: Maggie, did you two...you know...do...
answer: Do what?

question: That thing...that rabbits do a lot of and that a girl your age should never do and should only do when she's married.
answer: Sex? No, that's why he dumped me!

question: There, there now. It's okay.
answer: Sure he was a jerk but he was there for me. Which is more than I can say for any other man in my life.

question: When you're young everything seems like the end of the world. But it's not. It's just the beginning. And you might have to meet a few more jerks, but one day you'll meet a boy who treats you the way you deserve to be treated...like the sun rises and sets with you.
answer: You really think so?

question: I know so.
answer: You're so sweet.

question: I got'a use the bathroom.
answer: Mark? I didn't know you were there.

question: I'm sorry. You just look so beautiful.
answer: Thank you.

question: Can I zip you up?
answer: I'm wearing a sweater.

question: Your jeans? Stupid, idiot, stupid. Maggie, what...
answer: Shhh. I get it now. Why you didn't want me to be with Stan, the nice things you said in the library. It's because you wanted me.

question: Maggie, listen to me. I'm not the person you think...
answer: Shhh. Yes, you are. You're a good guy. You're not like the others.

question: That's right! I'm not like the others. I'm very different than the others. So different that you and I can never be...
answer: What are you trying to say? Are you..."confused"?

question: Yes! Yes! That's it. I'm confused. Extremely confused.
answer: Ohmygod! It all makes sense now! Your hair. The highlights.

question: What? No-no-no-no. I'm not gay. I'm...I've been in love with the same girl since I was 17.
answer: Who is it? Does she go to our school? Do I know her?

question: No, you don't. Now- -if you don't mind?
answer: Tell your girlfriend she better keep a close eye on you.

question: Don't you lay a finger on her, Johnson! I know where you live!
answer: It's weird to think about my mom with someone other than my dad.

question: It's adultery! If this were Afghanistan she'd be dragged through the village by goats. You need to talk to her.
answer: My mom's been pretty sad the past few months. She deserves to be happy. My dad obviously is...wherever he is.

question: Maybe he's not? Maybe he wishes he could be here right now with you but there's a real good reason he can't be.
answer: No, my dad's not a family guy. This is dumb but I used to tell him I was on the basketball team because I knew he'd never make it to a game.

question: Then why would you tell him that?
answer: I guess I was hoping it would make him like me more.

question: My wife's moving on. My son doesn't think I like him and my daughter's in love with me. I need to change back, Ed.
answer: What about college?

question: I'm not going. I'll be a pharm rep til I die. I just want my family back.
answer: Baby's got back.

question: Fine. I want to have some kids over tonight to celebrate Alex making the team. Is that cool?
answer: Wrap it up. No, it's not cool. I remember hearing what those parties were like, kids peeing everywhere, food on the ceilings, puke in the pool.

question: Listen to you. You sound like an old man.
answer: No party. I mean it. Don't make me take the car away.

question: Don't treat me like a child, Ed.
answer: I won't when you stop acting like one. This isn't over...son!

question: Party's over, Stan. You're out of here.
answer: Who's gonna make me leave? You?

question: I would but it smells like you've been drinking so I'll let the cops do it.
answer: You can have the nun. She doesn't put out anyway.

question: Thanks. Put this towards your studies.
answer: When you asked me to get together to talk about Mark this isn't what I envisioned. This isn't a date, Ed.

question: Are you insinuating that I'd use my son's misfortune just to go out with you? What kind of a father do you think I am?
answer: As long as we're on the same page.

question: Bring us the 1962 Petrus. You're going to love this wine. $2000 dollars a bottle.
answer: I don't drink. So tell me what you think's going on with Mark?

question: It's baffling really but I noticed he's been drinking a lot of diet ice tea lately. Maybe he's gay?
answer: You didn't ask me here to talk about Mark, did you?

question: Do you like caviar? Because if you do you have to try the Almas. 100 year-old Beluga. $700 per ounce.
answer: You're disgusting, Ed.

question: What? You don't like Beluga? You can get something else.
answer: I'm not some 22 year-old who you can impress with caviar and expensive wine.

question: Would the caviar and expensive wine impress you if you were on a yacht off Monte Carlo?
answer: I came here because I'm concerned about the wellbeing of your son but you don't care about Mark. All you're concerned with is proving to me how wealthy you are.

question: I do care about Mike...Mark. Whatever his name is.
answer: You know what's too bad, Ed? I'm sure when you were the guy the boys picked on and the girls ignored you were really sweet. But you thought becoming rich would solve all your problems. Instead it made you just like them. I have to go.

question: Wait. You're right. I'm acting like an idiot. I'm sorry. Please stay.
answer: Act normal or I'm leaving.

question: How about Mrs. Cruz? Every time she rolls her r's she spits all over me. Mike, I blew it! I totally blew it!
answer: Blew what? What happened?

question: She wanted me to kiss her but I panicked. I didn't know if I should close my eyes or which way to turn my head or how much tongue I'm supposed to use-
answer: Slow down. Have you ever kissed a girl before?

question: Not a real one. I used to practice on my dad's Playboys.
answer: How did you find...forget it. It's easy. All you have to do is take her face in your hands gently like -hold her still as you adjust your head, close your eyes and kiss her. The rest happens naturally.

question: What if I, you know, pitch a tent?
answer: If you feel it, you know, getting angry, take a step back. Now go get that kiss.

question: I'm so dead. Oh no! Scarlet, what are you doing here?
answer: I'm looking for Alex. It's past his curfew and he wasn't picking up his phone. Is he here?

question: Yeah, he's fine. He's with his girlfriend.
answer: Alex has a girlfriend?

question: How did you get your hands on the 5th edition? That's not due out for another three years.
answer: I have two words for you. Russian mafia.

question: Drive faster. Calm thyself, Marius.
answer: That little-! I'll kill him! Everybody out! Get out! Get out!

question: This party is over! If you don't want to spend the next 3 months in detention you will leave...now!
answer: Do you know where Mark Freedman is?

question: He's like a totally different person. It's been so good for him to have you around. You have no idea.
answer: Believe me, I do. He's a great kid. And you're an amazing mother.

question: I'm not so sure. I mean look at me. I showed up at a party to drag my son home. Could I be any more embarrassing? And how many amazing mothers run their kids' father off?
answer: Hey, you didn't run him off. Don't blame yourself for his stupidity.

question: I knew he was unhappy. I knew he hated his job. I should've been more supportive, more sympathetic to what he was going through. He gave up a lot for me.
answer: That's bull shit! You, Maggie and Alex are the best thing that ever happened to me...him. He was just too selfish to recognize it. At least, that's how I see it.

question: You're sweet. I have no idea why I'm telling you all this. There's just something so familiar... What do you think you're doing!?
answer: Scar, just calm down. I have something to tell you but I need you to keep an open mind. Can you do that for me?

question: This conversation is over, Mark.
answer: I'm not Mark.

question: I'm not in the mood for games.
answer: It's no game. I'm me...him...Mike. It's me...your husband.

question: What? Why would you say that?
answer: It's the truth. I'm the father of your children. You have to believe me.

question: Don't ever come near me or my family again. If you do, I'll have you arrested or better yet, institutionalized.
answer: Let me explain, Scar.

question: Who hates him? What's going on?
answer: Oh boy. I don't quite know how to put this.

question: Try being honest.
answer: He's not really my son. I don't have a son.

question: Mark's obviously having a crisis and you...you insensitive bastard, you disown him? He'd be better off with his mother in Thailand.
answer: Should I call you?! Come on. It's been 2 days. Open up. Jesus. It smells like Jeffrey Dahmer's kitchen in here. Are you alright?

question: Should I call you?! Come on. It's been 2 days. Open up. Jesus. It smells like Jeffrey Dahmer's kitchen in here. Are you alright?
answer: I really messed up. I've lost my family.

question: That's not true. Nothing's ever truly lost.
answer: What about you and Julie?

question: Oh, that? That's lost.
answer: Sorry about the party. I'll pay for any damages.

question: A well thought out plan. Good job.
answer: The mother will have full custody of the children. The father will have visitation rights of one weekend a month-

question: I declare a mistrial on the grounds of insufficient evidence and Sacco and Vanzetti!
answer: Sacco and...what are you....who are you!?

question: Maybe it wasn't a spell of enlightenment.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: According to the website once you've learned your lesson you'd turn back. That speech should've broken the spell.
answer: Enough with the magic crap, Ed.

question: You know what this means? You need to let them go. You need to let them get on with their lives and you need to get on with yours. Where you going?
answer: I'm moving on. See you at the game.

question: I'm moving on. See you at the game.
answer: Hey, Freedman, save some for the game.

question: Just warming up, Coach.
answer: Son, I haven't seen anyone with your shooting ability in, well, in a long time. I called a couple college scouts I know. They're coming to the game tonight...to watch you. If you have half the season I think you're capable of, you can play anywhere you want.

question: That's the plan, Coach.
answer: Round up, Jock Straps! Picture time.

question: I have nothing to say to you.
answer: I never meant to hurt you-

question: Then why'd you kiss my mom!?
answer: Alex, I'm your fa...I don't know. I'm sorry.

question: Julie, can I talk to you?
answer: What is it, Ed?

question: I've seen a good friend of mine lose everything that means anything to him. And maybe we'll never be there but...I just really want to play D & D with you.
answer: You can raid my dungeon anytime.
